content.description:
pull out of the water on some easy holds until you come to a blank 3-4 foot stretch where you can either find high feet for a reachy static move to the big flat hold above, or go for the short dyno while someone snaps a picture from the spectator section to your right.

 If you want a more challenging dyno (that you couldn't static even if you wanted to), skip the closer flat hold and launch for the big ledge about 2 feet higher, which probably ups the grade to v5 or so.
content.location: further left around the corner from the small cove

content.description: as the name implies, this route goes almost right up the nose of the arete feature facing the "stage" viewing area. the crux is finding a way to pull up on the ledge to finish.
content.location: this is right on the front of the right-facing prow, before the wall turns into the little cove

content.description: There's only one 40ish foot section of this wall that's very inviting to climb, but it has some really fun route options. It features a large overhanging arete that faces some big flat rocks that are great for spectating and taking pictures of the climbs, hence the wall name. To the left of the obvious arete is some easier, juggy vertical climbing. If you go far enough right into the little cove, the water gets questionably too shallow to climb if the water's low.
